coredata.dc:title: A theoretical study of the peroxo and superoxo forms of molecular oxygen on metal surfaces
coredata.dc:creator: Panas, Itai
Siegbahn, Per
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Simple cluster model calculations have been performed for the peroxo and superoxo forms of O2 on metal surfaces. The ionization spectra of superoxo-O2 on Ag(110) and Pt(111) and for peroxo-O2 on Ag(110) are predicted in good agreement with the most reliable experimental measurements. It is shown that the large qualitative difference between these spectra can be used to decide experimentally whether O2 is chemisorbed in the peroxo or superoxo form. The OO bond distance is calculated to be 1.32 Å for superoxo-O2 and 1.43 Å for peroxo-O2 in good agreement with the most recent NEXAFS measurements on Pt(111) and Ag(110), respectively. A problem in a recent analysis of a UPS spectrum for obtaining the OO bond distance is pointed out.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: volume 153, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 December 1988 A THEORETICAL STUDY OF THE PEROXO AND SUPEROXO FORMS OF MOLECULAR OXYGEN ON METAL SURFACES Itai PANAS and Per SIEGBAHN Institute of Theoretical Physics, Vanadissagen 9, S-113 46 Stockholm, Sweden Received IC) August 1988; in final form 15 October 1988 Simple cluster model calculations have been performed for the peroxo and superoxo forms of 02 on metal surfaces. The ioni- zation spectra of superoxo-02 on Ag( 110) and Pt( 111) and for peroxo-02 on Ag( 110) are predicted in good agreement with the most reliable experimental measurements. It is shown that the large qualitative difference between these speclra can be used to decide experimentally whether 02 is chemisorbed in the peroxo or superoxo form. The 0 0 bond distance is calculated lobe 1.32 A for superoxo-02 and 1.43 A for peroxo-02 in good agreement with the most recent NEXAFS measurements on Pt( Ill) and Ag( 110), respectively. A problem in a recent analysis of a UPS spectrum for obtaining the 0 0 bond distance is pointed out. 1. Introduction There has been considerable recent experimental interest in molecularly chemisorbed oxygen. There are three main reasons for this interest. First, the chemisorption of 02 is of interest in understanding the early stages of oxidation of metal surfaces in gen- eral. Second, chemisorbed 02 has served as a pro- totype system for testing new experimental surface techniques such as NEXAFS and photoemission. Third, molecularly chemisorbed oxygen is believed to play a role in the partial oxidation of ethylene to ethylene oxide catalyzed by supported silver which is an important petrochemical process [1]. On most metal surfaces 02 adsorbs dissociatively. Molecularly adsorbed oxygen (the a form) has, however, been observed on many metals, fof ex- ample, on polycrystalline gallium [2], copper, nickel, silver and gold [3]. Molecular oxygen has also been observed on well defined surfaces such as Cu (110) [4,5], Cu(l00) [5], Ag(ll0) [6 10], Ag(111) [11], Pt(lll) [8,12,13], Pt(llO) [14], Cr(llO) [15] and Pd(l00) [16]. The 0 0 stretching frequency for adsorbed oxy- gen has been measured for a few different metal stir- faces mainly by EELS. The results fall into two different categories, one with frequencies in the range 610 660 cm and another in the range 870 1020 cm ~ The frequencies obtained for 02 on Ag( 110) of63Ocm [9] andonCu(llO)of66Ocm [4] fall in the first category. The frequencies obtained forPt(lll)of87Ocmt [12] andforCr(110)of 1020 cm [15] fall in the second category. For polycrystalline copper two different frequencies, 610 and 880 cm , one in each category, were actually found [4]. It appears as if two different forms of molecular oxygen are present on these different sur- faces. Frequencies such as that for Pd( 100) [16] of 726 cm , which fall in between those of Ag(llO) and Pt (111), confuse this general picture somewhat. These different types of vibrational frequencies have generally been thought to come from differently chemisorbed (for example, on different sites), but the same form of 02, usually called a peroxo (Or) form or simply singlet oxygen [12]. There have also been some determinations of the bond distance for chemisorbed 02. The first NEXAFS measurement by Stdhr et al. was actually applied to 02 on Pt( 111) [7]. They obtained a bond distance of 1.45 A which is a dramatic increase of 0.24 A compared to the 0 0 distance of gas-phase oxygen of 1.21 A. Recently two new measurements have been made for 02 on Pt(l 11). One of them is another NEXAFS measurement with a new inter- pretation, which gives a much shorter 0 0 bond length of 1.32 0.05 A [8]. The other one is a photo- 0 009-2614/88/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publisbers B.Y. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 458 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 December icgs Volume 153, number 5 emission study, which was interpreted to give an 0 0 bond distance of 1.40 0.04 A [13 in quite good agreement with the first NEXAFS measure- ment of ref. [7], but in disagreement with the more recent NEXAFS measurement of ref. [81. In the lat- ter NEXAFS paper the bond distance of 02 on Ag(l10) is also given, as 1.47 0.05 A, and it is claimed that this is a different form of 02 from what is present on Pt(lll). On Ag(ll0) it should be a peroxo (0~) form while on Pt( 111) it should be a superoxo (Or) form. UPS studies have also given indications of two dif- ferent forms of molecular oxygen on metal surfaces [2,10). There is first a three-peak spectrum which has been characterized as a singlet form of 02 since there is no multiplet splitting. This form of 02 is called chemisorbed. There is also a five-peak spec- trum which includes the characteristic multiplet splitting from gas-phase 02 and it is therefore some- times called physisorbed 02. We have studied the 02 dissociation on Ni( 100) [17]. It was found that the dissociation mechanisms over the different sites were essentially the same even though the energetics were different. Some other fea- tures, for example concerning chemisorbed 02, were also found to be similar to what had experimentally been found even for other metal surfaces. We there- fore believe that the results from studies of this type can give general information which could shine light on some of the problems still remaining for chemi- sorption of molecular 02. In particular we have in- vestigated the photo-emission spectrum of the peroxo and superoxo forms of molecular oxygen on metal surfaces to see if the analysis of the spectrum for ob- taining the bond distance of 02 as has been done in ref. [13] is valid. We will also give a molecular-or- bital interpretation of the two forms of molecular 02 found on metal surfaces. 2. Computational details The superoxo form of the 02 molecule was ge- ometry-optimized in a fourfold hollow position on a Ni~ (square planar) cluster employing the com- plete active space self-consistent field (CM SCF) method [18]. Only the lc to surface and the 3cr~ bonds were correlated at the CM SCF level, while Eu to Eg excitations were found to be unimportant. Using the optimized 02 geometry from Ni402, the ionization energies were then determined using a larger Ni25 cluster as a model for the surface. The peroxo form of the 02 molecule has been ge- ometry-optimized previously in a fourfold hollow position on a Ni25 cluster [171. Using this optimized geometry the ionization energies were obtained for this same cluster exactly as for superoxo-02 de- scribed above. We will in the analysis below use the orbital ener- gies determined by Koopmans theorem as a mea- sure of the ionization energies. When there is a multiplet splitting, this splitting will be taken from the experimental spectrum for gas-phase 02 [19]. The relaxation and correlation contributions to the ionization energies are taken from a comparison of the calculated Koopmans energies to the experimen- tal ionization energies for gas-phase 02. This pro- cedure leads to only small corrections for the 3a and lit levels, but is important for the 2a levels. For these latter levels the relaxation is as large as 4 6 eV, which has to do with the localized nature of these inner-shell ionizations (the Koopmans holes are delocalized). This procedure for obtaining estimates of the actual ionization energies will be seen below to be quite suf- ficient for the present qualitative purposes. The ac- tual account of relaxation and correlation effects in the calculations is not impossible but is very tedious (convergence problems) and will not significantly improve the accuracy. In fact after full account of relaxation and correlation using the present basis set for the 2a5 level for gas-phase 02, an error of about I eV still remained. For the chemisorption energies it is necessary to include dynamical correlation effects. This was done using the externally contracted configuration inter- action (CCI) method [17,20]. The surface model was again the Ni25 cluster. Only the adsorbate va- lence electrons (except the oxygen 2s electrons) and the adsorbate to surface bonds were correlated. The nickel atoms were described as one-electron atoms using an effective core potential (ECP) pro- cedure where the 1 s 3d core electrons are replaced by a model potential. This potential includes the screened attraction of the nucleus and a projection operator to describe the repulsion of the core orbit- als. Finally, an attractive diffuse 3d projection op 459 Level Predicted Ag(ll0) Predicted Pt(l1l) Measured Ag(llO) Measured Pt(t11) 2~g 30.3 28.2 29.t 27.0 29.4 2a~ 21.1 18.7 19.9 17.5 17 20 21.2 3~g 12.6 10.2 11.4 9.0 14.2 11.9 11.8 9.5 Iz,~ 11.5 10.5 10.3 9.3 9 12 8 11 Ix,~ 9.2 8.2 8.0 7.0 9 12 8 11 lE~1 7.1 6.1 5.9 4.9 5 6 4 5 1it~1 6.0 4.8 5 6 4 5 Volume 153, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 December 1988 erator is added to counteract the exaggerated repulsion from the 3d projection operators. A basis set consisting of six primitive s contracted to four s functions and one p function was used for the five Ni atoms closest to the adsorbate. For the other nickel atoms a smaller basis without p functions was used and which had only four primitive s contracted to two s functions. This procedure is described in detail in ref. [211. It has been shown to give reliable results in a number of chemisorption studies [22 26]. For oxygen a contracted 4s, 3p basis set [27] aug- mented by a diffuse p function (exponent 0.059667) and a d function with the exponent 1.0 was used. 3. Results and discussion The ground state of the oxygen molecule is ~ with an orbital occupation 1 a~ 2a~ 3a~ 1 a~ 2a~ - lx~ ln~. The lOg and la~ orbitals are the oxygen ls orbitals and the 2a5 and the 2a~ orbitals the oxygen 2s orbitals. 3~g is the a bond and the lx,, the x-bind- ing orbital. The xg orbital which is half occupied the antibonding x orbital. Since there is one a bond and 2 1 it bonds, gas phase 02 has a double bond. In a side-on approach of an 02 molecule to a metal surface, the Ag orbital is split into two non-degen- erate components of which one is parallel and the other perpendicular to the surface. The perpendic- ular component will in the early stages of chemi- sorption form one bond to the surface. This form of 02 which has 1.5 bonds between the oxygens, is what has been termed physisorbed 02 since it will retain the same type of multiplet splitting as the gas-phase oxygen molecule. For physisorbed 02 this splitting comes from different couplings to the singly occu- pied orbital parallel to the surface. It is clear that the term physisorbed for this species is somewhat un- fortunate since 02 is not van der Waals bound but has a normal covalent bond to the surface. In the rest of this paper we therefore use the term superoxo-02 for this form of 02 since it gives a better description of the actual electronic structure. As the 02 molecule moves further down towards the surface there will be a large contribution to the wavefunction from a state where the oxygen mole- cule is excited from ~uI to it31~. With this excitation there is now a possibility for 02 to form two bonds down towards the surface. As these two bonds to the surface are formed, the oxygen molecule will be sin- glet coupled and lose its multiplet splitting. The two bonds to the surface will be polarized towards oxy- gen, and 02 will generally be charged by about 1.0. This is the peroxo form of 02, which has only a sin- gle bond between the oxygens. The predicted ionization spectra of superoxo-02 for Pt(lll) and Ag(l10) are given in table 1. These two predicted spectra are based on the same model calculation of 02 with only one bond towards the fourfold hollow site of a Ni( 100) surface (modelled by a 25-atom cluster). The ionization energies are as usual given with respect to the Fermi level, which is taken to be 4.5 eV for Ag and 5.65 eY for Pt. The two columns for predicted Ag( 110) and Pt(lll) will thus differ by 1.15 eV. The itg orbital parallel to the surface is singly occupied and causes the multiplet splittings. The fact that the Ag level is not fully oc- cupied in superoxo-02 is seen experimentally as a resonance level in the UPS spectrum [8,13]. The predicted spectrum for 02 on Ag (110) is compared, in table 1, to an angle-resolved photoemission ex- periment of superoxo-02 (physisorbed 02) by Prince et al. [101. The calculated spectrum is also com- pared in this table to the photoemission spectrum of Table I Predicted ionization spectrum of superoxo-02 on Ag( 110) and Pt(111). The experimental spectra are taken from Prince et al. forAs(1l0) [7],andrromEberhardtetaLrorPt(l1l) 113]. The z-axis is perpendicular to the surface 460 Level Predicted Ag(1l0) Predicted Pt(l1l) Measured Ag(ltO) Measured P1(111) 2c~ 23.6 22.4 29.4 2a,, 16.8 15.6 21.2 3c2 6.6 5.4 6.6 11.8 lst.. 5.5 4.3 4.0 8 11 lit~ 6.0 4.8 4.0 8 lI lEg1 2.8 1.6 3.0 45 1it~~. 1.4 0.2 0.8 4-5 Volume 153, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 23 December 1988 significantly from what has normally been given. In UPS, peroxo-02 is identified by the appearance of a three-peak spectrum. These three peaks found ex- perimentally at 6.2, 9.8 and 13.0 eV for copper, for example, have nearly always been assigned as due to it5, it,, and a~ respectively [4], in total disagreement with the assignment in table 2. For clean copper without any oxygen there is a UPS peak at around 2 eV. When 02 is added this peak will have a shoul- der noticed by, for example, Spitzer and Luth [5]. This shoulder is what we assign to the it5 level. Ex- perimentally it has been assigned to an antibonding Cu (d) 0 (2p) orbital. Such antibonding orbitals are not found to be occupied in our calculations and will thus be above the Fermi level. The peak observed experimentally at around 6 eV has been assigned to both a chemisorbed atomic oxygen 2p level and the 02 it5 level. The first part of this assignment has to be correct since the peak is still present when there is only atomically chemisorbed oxygen left after the sample has been heated. We suggest, however, that the rest of the structure in this region is due to both it,, and a~, but not no it5 as suggested experimentally. The peaks at around 10 and 13 eV, which are found on copper have no correspondence in our predicted spectrum of peroxo-02. The most likely explanation is that these peaks instead are due to either some contamination of the sample or possibly to the 3a~ and lx,, levels of superoxo-02. It should also be noted that these peaks are not seen in the spectrum of chemisorbed 02 on Ag( 110) measured by Prince et al. [10]. The agreement between the predicted spectrum of peroxo-02 on Ag (110) and the measured spectrum by Barteau and Madix is very good. The agreement between our spectrum and that measured by Prince et al. 1101 is also reasonable. They find the 3a5 peak at 8.2 eY rather than at 6.6 eV. This deviation of 1.6 eV must be considered to be close to the uncertainty in our predictions. Based on our present qualitative calculations we can thus not judge which of the two measured values should be considered most reliable. The same is true also for the other, even smaller de- viations between these two measured spectra. The agreement between our spectrum and those calcu- lated by Selmani et al. [28], using very different the- oretical methods, is also reasonably good. This leaves no doubt in our minds that the gross features of the O2onPt(lll)byEberhardtetal. [13]. The predicted ionization spectra of peroxo-02 for Ag(llO) and Pt(lll) are given in table 2. In this case there is no multiplet splitting since all the or- bitals on 02 are doubly occupied. Since also the A5 orbital is fully occupied for peroxo-02 this orbital will not give rise to a resonance in the UPS spectrum as it does for superoxo-02. The predicted spectra are compared in table 2 with the spectrum of chemi- sorbed 02 on Ag( 110) measured by Barteau and Madix [6] and the same 02 on Pt(1 11) spectrum of Eberhardt et al. as was given in table I. The reason for giving the same Pt (111) spectrum both in tables 1 and 2 is that it is of importance for the present analysis if the form of 02 observed on Pt( 111) should be considered as a peroxo or a superoxo form and this is best seen in a comparison to the predicted spectra. It is immediately clear from the comparisons in the tables that the measured photoemission spec- trum of 02 on Pt(lll) by Eberhardt et al. is that of superoxo-02. In particular the two multiplet-splitted 3a~ levels at 9.5 and 11.8 eV are clearly seen in their spectrum (however not identified as such by them). Also the positions of the 2a levels fit well with the predicted superoxo-02 levels but are 6 7 eY too high to be due to peroxo-02. Overall, the agreement be- tween the predicted and measured spectra for Pt (Ill) as shown in table 1 must be considered to be very good. The assignment of the peaks of peroxo-02 on metal surfaces has not been completely clear experimen- tally. In fact our assignment given in table 2 differs Table 2 Predicted ionization spectrum of peroxo-02 on Ag( 1101 and P1(111). The experimental spectra are taken from Barteau and Madix for Ag(1 10) 161, and from Eberhardt et al. for P1(111) 113]. The z-axis is perpendicular to the surface 461 volume 153, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEITERS 23 December 1988 predicted spectra in tables 1 and 2 must be correct. As noted in section 1 the most recent NEXAFS measurement of 02 on Pt (111) gives an 0 0 bond distance of 1.32 0.05 A. Since we now known, from the comparison of the UPS spectra in table 1, that this form of 02 is the superoxo form, we can then go ahead and optimize the 0 0 bond distance with the wavefunction characteristic of this form of 02. When this is done we obtain 1.32 A, which somewhat for- tuitously agrees perfectly with the NEXAFS result. The charge of 02 becomes 0.53. Our results thus agree totally with the results from this NEXAFS study even considering the form of 02 which is observed, namely a superoxo (0~) form. We have already noted that our predicted UPS spectrum of 02 on Pt (111) agrees very well with the measurements of Eberhardt et al., provided 02 is considered to be in the superoxo form. In fact also the experimental assignment of the spectrum agrees with our calculations for most of the levels (apart from the multiplet splitting). However, this UPS spectrum was used by Eberhardt et al. to obtain the 0 0 bond distance of 1.40 0.04 A, which disagrees both with the recent NEXAPS experiment and with our prediction. This means that something in the analysis to reach the bond distance has not been fully correct. A new interesting method was used by Eberhardt et al. to deduce the bond distance from the spectrum. They noticed that the splitting be- tween the 2a levels is very characteristic of the bond distance. The splitting plotted as a function of the 0 0 distance is a smooth curve going from a small splitting at longer distances to larger splittings as the bond gets shorter. We have tested this procedure and at this point we are in perfect agreement with Eberhardt et al.: The splitting is a very good measure of the 0 0 bond distance. This splitting has, how- ever, to be taken from an average of the multiplet- splitted 2a peaks in this case since 02 is chemisorbed in the superoxo rather than the peroxo form. The multiplet splitting has not been observed by Eberhardt et al. and here lies most of the problem. When we take the splitting between our averaged 2cr levels we find that it is 3.3 eV smaller than the split- ting for free 02 at its equilibrium bond length 1.21 A. With this value we obtain 1.32 A for the bond dis- tance if we use the calibration curve given by Eberhardt et al. (our calculated curve agrees per- fectly with their curve). If the same comparison is made to free 0~ the value 1.33 A is obtained. These values are in good agreement with our actually op- timized value for the bond distance, 1.32 A (see above). We thus obtain a completely consistent pic- ture for both the UPS spectrum and the bond dis- tance. When Eberhardt et al. use their measured spectrum they identify only one of the multiplet- splitted peaks and obtain a decrease of the splitting of the 2cr levels compared to gas phase 02 of 5.4 eV, which is 2.1 eV larger than our value. The 5.4 eV de- crease in the splitting leads them to their final esti- mate of 1.40 A for the 0 0 bond distance. There is consequently nothing wrong in the method for ob- taining the bond distance, but the whole problem lies in identifying the 2cr peaks in the spectrum. When this can safely be done this method will be an ex- tremely useful tool for obtaining adsorbate bond distances. When the 0 0 bond distance of peroxo-02 is op- timized we obtain the value 1.43 A, which is also in reasonable agreement with the recent NEXAFS value of 1.47 0.05 A for 02 onAg(ll0). We thus agree that there are two different forms of 02 on Pt (111) and Ag(l 10). The former is a superoxo (Oj-) form and the latter is a peroxo (0~ ) form. The splitting between the two 2cr levels of peroxo-02 is 8.6 eV, which is 5.9 eV less than for gas phase O~. Using the curve given by Eberhardt et al., this leads to an 0 0 bond distance of 1.43 A, in perfect agreement with the optimized bond distance. The splitting of the 2cr levels is thus again shown to be a quite ac- curate method for obtaining the bond distance in principle. Since there is no multiplet splitting be- tween the 2cr levels for peroxo-02 this method is probably easier to use experimentally in this case. Eberhardt et al. also suggest the use of the splitting between the 2cr~ and the 3cr5 levels as a measure of the 0 0 bond distance. Also with this procedure we find bond lengths which are completely consistent with our predicted spectra. For superoxo-02 there is no problem to identi& the two 3; peaks at 9.5 and 11.8 eV in the experimental spectrum. However, ac- cording to our predicted spectrum the two 2o peaks should be at about 18 and 20 eV, but this region is not well enough resolved in the experimental spec- trum for making a certain assignment. Again, a bet- ter resolution of the 2cr region of the spectrum is 462 23 December 1988 volume 153, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS required for making this procedure useful for the de- termination of adsorbate bond distances. The final problem we address in this paper is the reaction pathway between the superoxo and the per- oxo forms of 02 on a metal surface. It has been noted by, for example, Schmeisser and Jacobi [2] that the existence of an activation barrier between these two forms of oxygen is somewhat surprising. With the molecular orbital descriptions of the two forms of 02 given above, the activation barrier is easier to un- derstand. An activation barrier always arises because there is a crossing between two potential surfaces (which may be avoided or not). The binding of su- peroxo-02 proceeds along the ground-state potential energy surface for 02 and there should thus be no barrier to form superoxo-02. To form the two bonds down to the surface as required to form peroxo-02, the 02 molecule has to be excited from ~ ~ to it5 as mentioned above. This means that the excited 02 curve will come down and cross the ground state curve at some point and can thus lead to an acti- vation barrier. An activation barrier is particularly expected when the binding energies of the superoxo and peroxo forms of chemisorbed 02 are about the same. For Ni (100), however, our calculations give a superoxo-02 minimum of 43.5 kcal /mol and a per- oxo-02 minimum as deep as 78.0 kcal/mol. This means that for Ni (100) the potential curve for per- oxo-02 is lower than the curve for superoxo-02 even at the minimum of the latter species. Superoxo-02 will therefore never form and there will conse- quently not be any barrier between the two forms of 02 on this surface (for a full discussion of the 02 dis- sociation process on the Ni (100) surface we refer to our calculations in ref [17]). For other metal sur- faces, particularly when 02 is weakly chemisorbed, the existence of a barrier between the two forms of 02 is on the other hand quite likely. 4. Conclusions Cluster model calculations have shown that the ionization spectra of the superoxo and peroxo forms of 02 on metal surfaces are qualitatively different. This difference is due to the different chemical or- igin of the binding in the two forms of 02. The bind- ing of superoxo-02 involves the ground state of 02 whereas the binding of peroxo-02 involves an ex- cited it,, to n~ state of 02. Due to the large difference between the two spectra, the position of the levels can be used to unequivocally decide whether 02 is chemisorbed in the superoxo or peroxo form. This fact has not been fully realized experimentally. For example, in a recent measurement on 02 on Pt (110) [14] a 2; level at 27.5 eV and a 2cr,, level at 18 eV are found. Comparing this result with our predic- tions in tables 1 and 2, it is clear that 02 is chemi- sorbed in the superoxo form on Pt( 110), not in the peroxo form as claimed experimentally. A superoxo form of 02 on Pt (110) is furthermore more in line with the recent NEXAFS measurements on 02 on Pt( 111), whereas it is definitely established that 02 has the superoxo form [5]. A point of further in- terest for 02 on Pt( 110) is that a peak appears at 21.5 eY 10 15 mm after adsorption. This peak is as- signed to the atomic oxygen 2s level formed by dis- sociation on the surface. Another possibility, suggested by inspection of table 2, is that this peak is due to the 2; level of peroxo-02. Based on results of this type we conclude that theoretical model cal- culations can be useful for analyzing experimental surface results and should in our opinion be used more often than has been the case. Salahub, Surface Sci. 157 (1985) 208. 464 tal surfaces are qualitatively different. This difference is due to the different chemical or- igin of the binding in the two forms of 02. The bind- ing of superoxo-02 involves the ground state of 02 whereas the binding of peroxo-02 involves an ex- cited it,, to n~ state of 02. Due to the large difference between the two spectra, the position of the levels can be used to unequivocally decide whether 02 is chemisorbed in the superoxo or peroxo form. This fact has not been fully realized experimentally. For example, in a recent measurement on 02 on Pt (110) [14] a 2; level at 27.5 eV and a 2cr,, level at 18 eV are found. Comparing this result with our predic- tions in tables 1 and 2, it is clear that 02 is chemi- sorbed in the superoxo form on Pt( 110), not in the peroxo form as claimed experimentally. A superoxo form of 02 on Pt (110) is furthermore more in line with the recent NEXAFS measurements on 02 on Pt( 111), whereas it is definitely established that 02 has the superoxo form [5]. A point of further in- terest for 02 on Pt( 110) is that a peak appears at 21.5 eY 10 15 mm after adsorption. This peak is as- signed to the atomic oxygen 2s level formed by dis- sociation on the surface. Another possibility, suggested by inspection of table 2, is that this peak is due to the 2; level of peroxo-02. Based on results of this type we conclude that theoretical model cal- culations can be useful for analyzing experimental surface results and should in our opinion be used more often than has been the case. head.ce:title: A theoretical study of the peroxo and superoxo forms of molecular oxygen on metal surfaces

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institute of Theoretical Physics, Vanadisvagen 9, S-113 46 Stockholm, Sweden

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Simple cluster model calculations have been performed for the peroxo and superoxo forms of O2 on metal surfaces. The ionization spectra of superoxo-O2 on Ag(110) and Pt(111) and for peroxo-O2 on Ag(110) are predicted in good agreement with the most reliable experimental measurements. It is shown that the large qualitative difference between these spectra can be used to decide experimentally whether O2 is chemisorbed in the peroxo or superoxo form. The OO bond distance is calculated to be 1.32 Å for superoxo-O2 and 1.43 Å for peroxo-O2 in good agreement with the most recent NEXAFS measurements on Pt(111) and Ag(110), respectively. A problem in a recent analysis of a UPS spectrum for obtaining the OO bond distance is pointed out.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: The chemical physics of solid surfaces and heterogeneous catalysis

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: I. Panas, P. Siegbahn and U. Wahlgren, to be published.
I. Panas, P. Siegbahn and U. Wahlgren, Theoret. Chim. Acta, to be published.
J. Schüle, P. Siegbahn and U. Wahlgren, J. Chem. Phys., to be published.
